messageBody:
One thing you could do is create the file on the fly,
and feed it to your class. I don't know what language
you're using, but in Java I'd probably have the class
that does the parsing take an InputStream instead of a
File. Either way, the test(s) could create the file
beforehand and blast the file when the test is
finished.

-Eric

--- "David V. Olivier" <dolivier@...>
wrote:
> The rule of thumb is that unit tests should be as
> standalone as possible,
> and dependencies on external resources such as
> databases or files should be
> minimized or eliminated. This makes perfect sense.
> Tests which rely on
> external resources are not self-contained, are
> harder to read, and can be
> broken even if the code is functioning correctly.
> However, code does touch
> external resources at some point. Shouldn't this be
> tested, and how?
>
> Specifically, I have code that parses a xml catalog
> file and builds a
> catalog object structure. I want to verify that the
> parsing works
> correctly. In particular, I want to make sure that
> it robustly handles
> unusual conditions such as catalogs with certain
> branches missing. It
> seems to me that the simplest way to do this is to
> have a test which uses
> the parsing code to parse a very simple catalog and
> verifies that it builds
> what I expect it to.
>
> But to do this test I do need some external
> resource, a simple catalog
> file. Ok. Now I can't simply look at the test to
> see what it does. I
> also have to look at the file. Are there cleaner
> alternatives? Must I
> simply accept that there will occasionally be
> external resources required
> to test functionality at the boundaries of the
> system? If so, are there
> best practices for this scenario? Am I missing
> something? I'd love to
> hear peoples thoughts.
>
>
>
> David Olivier
